Our Chief Executive @JamesBevanEA has today warned businesses & government that we must reach #NetZero while also becoming more resilient to #ClimateChange: https://t.co/Dejc7QSbmz

For example, we're using more low-carbon concrete in flood defences ‚¨áÔ∏è 

#TogetherForOurPlanet https://t.co/sdnXtuwL11

@BierbergThomas @DefraGovUK @CITES @EnvAgency @EelGroup Bit of both the last 5/6 years eel numbers have been increasing so most Europe is filled up before we start fishing so brexit should of helped but @DefraGovUK @CITES @EnvAgency aren‚Äôt helping the situation

Do you suffer from #WasteCrime or #Bonfires causing smoke pollution from private and commercial developers burning toxic materials near families working at home üè°? - report Incidents to the @EnvAgencyMids hotline: 0800 807 060 who work with other ESA services and issue Fines https://t.co/02R7h74dJM

urls.title: Keeping Rivers Cool - CaBA
urls.description: Keeping Rivers Cool was a four year (2012-2016) Environment Agency led climate change adaptation project, which focused on using trees to keep rivers cool.

tweets.text:
@wiguk @BillGates @EnvAgency @metoffice #NetZero and adaptation are two sides of the same coin. The best climate interventions do both at the same time. Example: the recent Keeping Rivers Cool project, under which  EA worked with partners to plant trees along several of our rivers. 

https://t.co/wQW3tsI4MA

urls.title: Flash flooding from rivers | The Flood Hub
urls.description: The information on this page has been provided by the Environment Agency and was correct at the time of upload. Flash flooding usually results from intense and heavy rainfall. It occurs in areas where rivers are very responsive to heavy rainfall. Unlike most other types of flooding, the localised nature and speed of the river response means that flooding can occur before flood warnings are issued. Precisely where flash floods will strike can be difficult to predict accurately as it can occur in places
